title: 107_hr4963
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cancer Survivorship Research and Quality of Life Act of 2002". The Congress finds that there are over 9,000,000 cancer survivors in the US, with 60% being 65 years or older. 62% of adults diagnosed with cancer today will live 5 years from now. In 1960, only 4% of children with cancer survived more than 5 years, but now 77% of children diagnosed with cancer will live five years from now. Three out of four American families will have a member diagnosed with cancer, and 24% of adult cancer patients are parents with young children at home. In 2002, 555,500 Americans will die of cancer, costing the US $180 billion annually. The National Institutes of Health invested $38 million in survivorship in fiscal year 2001. SEC. 3. Amends the Public Health Service Act to include survivorship in cancer control programs. SEC. 4. Expands and coordinates NIH activities for cancer survivorship research. Expansion and coordination of activities with respect to cancer survivorship research. The Director of NIH will expand and coordinate activities related to cancer survivorship research. An Office on Survivorship will be established within the Institute to implement and direct these activities. An Associate Director for survivorship will be appointed to assist in this effort. The Institute will have an Associate Director for Survivorship to oversee cancer survivorship research programs. The Associate Director will be appointed by the Institute's Director and will submit a report to Congress on survivorship activities and future strategies by February 1, 2003. Funding for these activities will be addressed in Section 417B(d)(2) of the Public Health Service Act. Funding for survivorship activities under the Public Health Service Act will be 13 percent for fiscal year 2003 and beyond, with at least 3 percent allocated to the Office on Survivorship. SEC. 5. Expansion of CDC comprehensive cancer programs to improve cancer survivorship. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, will study health challenges of cancer survivorship and implement projects to enhance survivors' long-term health. This includes expanding cancer surveillance systems, assessing survivorship challenges, and developing a national survivorship program. The development of a national cancer survivorship action plan in partnership with health organizations to support cancer survivors through physical activity, education for healthcare providers, and programs to improve quality of life. The national cancer survivorship action plan includes interventions like peer support programs, public awareness campaigns, and information dissemination for healthcare providers. Additionally, unique survivorship programs will be developed for underserved populations. Coordination of activities will be ensured by the Secretary. The Secretary will coordinate activities with other agencies of the Public Health Service. A report on the evaluation results and strategies will be submitted to Congress by October 1, 2003. $75,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003, with additional funding for fiscal years 2004 through 2006. SEC. 399E-1. MONITORING AND EVALUATING QUALITY CANCER CARE AND CANCER SURVIVORSHIP. The Secretary will make grants to eligible entities to monitor and evaluate quality cancer care, develop information on quality cancer care, and monitor cancer survivorship. Eligible entities must operate a statewide cancer registry and be certified by a recognized organization. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities to contract with academic institutions, cancer centers, and other entities as needed. Grants can only be made if an application is submitted with necessary information. The Secretary will determine the appropriate use of grants to achieve the section's purpose. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. Appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. Amendment made to Public Health Service Act regarding authorization of appropriations.
